string_table.string: To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.
Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.

slidelink.displaytext: How Safe Is Your Kid Online?

search.slidetext: online exploitation a note of caution: this module includes mature language and may include readings, media, and discussion around topics such as sexual assault, child sexual abuse, human trafficking, online sexual enticement, domestic violence, and physical violence. hope for justice acknowledges that this content may be difficult and encourages participants to care for their safety and well-being. disclaimer: some of the stories in this module are based on real survivors. names are fictional and images use models to protect survivor identities. start the module start the module start the module keeping kids safe in the digital world

how safe is your kid online? my child is safe online. i limit him to educational games. i approve all the apps my kid uses. i’ve told my kids not to talk to anyone they don’t know online. i’ve turned off location settings. watch what happens to gabriella. continue continue continue

predators use trickery, false identity, and fraud. the truth about online exploitation why kids are vulnerable how exploitation happens how to spot the signs there has been more than a 90% increase in online enticement reports. the majority of child exploitation is undetected or under-detected. online exploitation learn about online exploitation. continue continue continue many parents and caretakers try to keep their kids safe online. but these safety measures are often not enough.

this is fiction. online exploitation is a criminal act that involves one person manipulating another to get them to do something against their will. it can take many forms, not just sharing sexual images or videos, although that’s common. continue continue continue this is fiction. online exploitation is a criminal act that involves one person manipulating another to get them to do something against their will. it can take many forms, not just sharing sexual images or videos, although that’s common. continue continue continue what do you think? online exploitation is limited to sharing sexual images or videos. choose one. fact fact fact fact fiction fiction fiction fiction
predators are manipulative. they groom the victim. they exploit from a distance. they lure victims offline.

sexually explicit material predators may share pornography or sexually explicit photos with victims as a way of normalizing deviant sexual behavior. livestreaming offenders lure young people into private rooms for live video conversations. they may convince the child to strip or perform sexual acts while they secretly record the session. these videos fuel further “sextortion.” secrets and sextortion predators leverage emotional bonds to convince kids to share explicit pictures of themselves or tell embarrassing secrets. they then threaten to publish the pictures or secrets to get the victim to provide increasingly more explicit images or send money (a practice referred to as “sextortion”). grooming offenders target vulnerable young people. they "groom" young people by developing online relationships—showering attention, compliments, and understanding—with the goal of developing an emotional bond they can ultimately manipulate. sexually explicit material sexually explicit material sexually explicit material sexually explicit material livestreaming livestreaming livestreaming livestreaming secrets and sextortion secrets and sextortion secrets and sextortion secrets and sextortion grooming grooming grooming grooming continue continue continue click to see what online exploitation includes.

online exploitation can be a pathway into human trafficking. traffickers entice adult and minor victims to perform sex acts or labor. traffickers use force, fraud, or coercion to prey on adult victims. minors can’t consent, so any sexual act with a minor is criminal. traffickers use the internet strategically. victims can find it hard to escape.

? there is no limit to finding potential victims. 93% of kids aged 12-17 are online. kids are posting messages. chatting with friends. doing homework. watching and playing games or videos. many kids are not using apps safely.

predators know how to stay anonymous. they pose as different people to target, groom, and exploit. they evade detection through advanced online storage, hosting services, or encryption. predatory behavior is facilitated by app functions. private and public channels make it easy to meet new people and then move conversations into private chats. some apps allow users to hide or permanently delete explicit images or content, making it difficult to track predatory activity. public location settings show where users are geographically located. many kids do not use online apps safely. about 1 in 20 young people have arranged a secret meeting with someone they met online.* online sexting and sharing nude photos are increasingly common activities among young people. *pew research center, 2019 anonymity anonymity anonymity anonymity app functions app functions app functions app functions safety issues safety issues safety issues safety issues continue continue continue click each topic to learn more about why the internet is any easy place to target kids.
learn why kids are vulnerable. continue continue continue

this is fiction. there is no universal victim profile. both girls and boys are targeted. predators know that many young people are naïve to begin with, but they also look for other indicators of vulnerability. this is why it’s so important to understand the emotional, social, and physical factors that can make young people vulnerable. continue continue continue this is fiction. there is no universal victim profile. both girls and boys are targeted. predators know that many young people are naïve to begin with, but they also look for other indicators of vulnerability. this is why it’s so important to understand the emotional, social, and physical factors that can make young people vulnerable. continue continue continue what do you think? online exploitation typically happens to certain types of people. choose one. fact fact fact fact fiction fiction fiction fiction
liam's story

let's explore this more. predators are experts at targeting kids with vulnerabilities similar to liam's. they understand how young people desperately want to fit in and be accepted. predators know kids are inherently vulnerable because they are still developing physically and socially. they specifically watch for victims who feel isolated, insecure, or misunderstood. they target kids with troubles at home or who have physical, mental, or emotional challenges. and when kids like liam are appreciated and accepted online, they are likely to trust those relationships. continue continue continue continue good choices. predators are experts at targeting kids with vulnerabilities similar to liam's. they understand how young people desperately want to fit in and be accepted. predators know kids are inherently vulnerable because they are still developing physically and socially. they specifically watch for victims who feel isolated, insecure, or misunderstood. they target kids with troubles at home or who have physical, mental, or emotional challenges. and when kids like liam are appreciated and accepted online, they are likely to trust those relationships. continue continue continue continue continue continue continue he has low self-esteem. he’s stressed about schoolwork. he lacks friends at school. he’s bullied at school. what might make liam vulnerable to seeking online connection and escape? choose all that apply and click continue.
learn how it happens. continue continue continue

this is fiction. online predators rely on anonymity. in the digital world, predators can pretend to be any age or gender to attract a potential victim. some use devices to change their voice at will—allowing them to sound male or female, young or old. continue continue continue this is fiction. online predators rely on anonymity. in the digital world, predators can pretend to be any age or gender to attract a potential victim. some use devices to change their voice at will—allowing them to sound male or female, young or old. continue continue continue what do you think? online predators are easy to spot. choose one. fact fact fact fact fiction fiction fiction fiction
hi alicia! initiation grooming progression manipulation exploitation phases of online exploitation success! jordan, you’ve uploaded a new profile pic.

initiation grooming progression manipulation exploitation initiation to make contact, the predator: identifies and observes a victim discovers vulnerabilities, interests, and desires befriends a victim using flattery, attention, and empathy see what happens next. see what happens next. see what happens next. talk tomorrow??

initiation grooming progression manipulation exploitation grooming to build a strong relationship, the predator: plays to the victim's dreams, desires, and challenges listens attentively makes the victim feel special offers compliments, gifts, and false promises see what happens next. see what happens next. see what happens next.

initiation grooming progression manipulation exploitation progression to cement the relationship, the predator: develops dependency and exclusivity uses secrecy and empathy isolates the victim from their inner circle see what happens next. see what happens next. see what happens next.

initiation grooming progression manipulation exploitation manipulation to get compromising content, the predator: leverages a victim's dependency uses isolation appeals to a victim's dreams and desires see what happens next. see what happens next. see what happens next. u there?

initiation grooming progression manipulation exploitation exploitation to control and exploit, the predator may: get the victim to meet in person demand more explicit images threaten to share images or secrets threaten to harm the victim/their inner circle demand money
alicia’s story might not end here… online exploitation can lead to human trafficking with tragic consequences.
learn how to spot the signs. continue continue continue

this is fiction. sadly, a study found that 81% of sextortion cases go unreported.* victims are often too embarrassed or ashamed to tell anyone. young people are especially horrified by the prospect of public humiliation if explicit images are shared with friends, family, or school officials. this fear overrides their ability to weigh the short-term price of public embarrassment or losing privileges against the long-term physical dangers of being kidnapped, raped, or worse, if they continue the predator relationship or agree to meet in person. continue continue continue *journal of adolescent health, 2017. this is fiction. sadly, a study found that 81% of sextortion cases go unreported.* victims are often too embarrassed or ashamed to tell anyone. young people are especially horrified by the prospect of public humiliation if explicit images are shared with friends, family, or school officials. this fear overrides their ability to weigh the short-term price of public embarrassment or losing privileges against the long-term physical dangers of being kidnapped, raped, or worse, if they continue the predator relationship or agree to meet in person. continue continue continue *journal of adolescent health, 2017. what do you think? victims of online exploitation typically tell other people when they are being exploited. choose one. fact fact fact fact fiction fiction fiction fiction
noah’s story

let's explore this more. continue continue continue continue young people being exploited online might show any or all of these signs. they may spend more time alone or stop eating, sleeping, or performing well in school. they might spend excessive amounts of time online and become very secretive about their internet activities. if they are being “sextorted,” their funds could disappear and they may attempt to borrow or even steal money. while one sign alone may not indicate a problem, multiple signs should be cause for alarm and investigation by parents or guardians. remember, most teens in situations like this are too ashamed or scared to tell anyone. good choices. young people being exploited online might show any or all of these signs. they may spend more time alone or stop eating, sleeping, or performing well in school. they might spend excessive amounts of time online and become very secretive about their internet activities. if they are being “sextorted,” their funds could disappear and they may attempt to borrow or even steal money. while one sign alone may not indicate a problem, multiple signs should be cause for alarm and investigation by parents or guardians. remember, most teens in situations like this are too ashamed or scared to tell anyone. continue continue continue continue continue continue continue he needs to borrow money. he receives calls and messages from a stranger. he is online excessively and is secretive about online activities. he is anxious and withdrawing from family and friends. what signs might indicate noah is in trouble with an online situation? choose all that apply and click continue.
ready to learn how to safeguard kids online? continue continue continue

digital safeguarding a note of caution: this module includes mature language and may include readings, media, and discussion around topics such as sexual assault, child sexual abuse, human trafficking, online sexual enticement, domestic violence, and physical violence. hope for justice acknowledges that this content may be difficult and encourages participants to care for their safety and well-being. disclaimer: some of the stories in this module are based on real survivors. names are fictional and images use models to protect survivor identities. start the module start the module start the module keeping kids safe in the digital world
how do you keep kids safe? devices and apps are central to how kids create, learn, play, and connect. how would you handle this situation? continue continue continue

all these are natural responses. situations like emi's, in which a young person has misused technology or is in danger can be challenging. you may be tempted to simply ban young people from apps or devices. but technology-banning as a safety approach often causes communication breakdown between adults and youth. often the best steps for preventing and addressing a situation like emi's include a combination of talking to a youth in your life about their online activities and safety, gaining a greater understanding of the platforms they are using (including parental controls), and taking immediate action if an online situation feels suspicious or dangerous. let’s explore this more. continue continue continue all these are natural responses. situations like emi's, in which a young person has misused technology or is in danger can be challenging. you may be tempted to simply ban young people from apps or devices. but technology-banning as a safety approach often causes communication breakdown between adults and youth. often the best steps for preventing and addressing a situation like emi's include a combination of talking to a youth in your life about their online activities and safety, gaining a greater understanding of the platforms they are using (including parental controls), and taking immediate action if an online situation feels suspicious or dangerous. let’s explore this more. continue continue continue continue continue continue continue you would create new house rules around technology use. you would look at emi’s devices to learn more about this boy from england. you would talk to both your kids about safe technology use. you would ban emi from all devices. how would you handle this situation? choose all that are true for you and click continue.

you're ready to use the 3 ts! continue continue continue ur really good at the new quest game send pix?? stories like this are more and more prevalent. it can feel impossible... 3 ts of online safety click each digital safeguarding approach. talk to kids regularly talk to kids regularly talk to kids regularly technology awareness and control technology awareness and control technology awareness and control take action to intervene take action to intervene take action to intervene a mother spotted the signs of online grooming.

that’s understandable. having conversations about topics like sexual exploitation can be uncomfortable! but it's important to have safety talks with kids of all ages, so they feel comfortable sharing about their online experiences, especially if they start to feel unsafe. these preventative conversations can be age-appropriate and aligned with your family’s communication style. the key is talking to your young person regularly and being willing to address topics that may be uncomfortable at first. continue continue continue that’s understandable. it makes sense to be concerned about safety conversations based on a child’s age. but it's important to have safety talks with kids of all ages, so they feel comfortable sharing about their online experiences, especially if they start to feel unsafe. these preventative conversations can be age-appropriate and aligned with your family’s communication style. the key is talking to your young person regularly and being willing to address topics that may be uncomfortable at first. continue continue continue that’s understandable. sometimes conversation starters, tips, and topics are all that’s needed to get started. but it's important to have safety talks with kids of all ages, so they feel comfortable sharing about their online experiences, especially if they start to feel unsafe. these preventative conversations can be age-appropriate and aligned with your family’s communication style. the key is talking to your young person regularly and being willing to address topics that may be uncomfortable at first. continue continue continue that’s great! it's important to have safety talks with kids of all ages, so they feel comfortable sharing about their online experiences, especially if they start to feel unsafe. these preventative conversations can be age-appropriate and aligned with your family’s communication style. the key is talking to your young person regularly and being willing to address topics that may be uncomfortable at first. continue continue continue continue continue continue continue it feels too uncomfortable to talk about sextortion or internet pornography with a child. the child in my life is young; i don’t want to scare them. it sounds daunting; i see the importance, but i don’t know how to have the conversation. it’s important, and i’ve already started having these conversations. can you relate to any of these common feelings about talking to kids about online safety? choose the response that’s most true for you and click continue.

a study involving parents and kids found... parents and caretakers are the most important influencers in shaping online behavior. it’s critical to create open communication about online safety. talk to kids regularly click to learn more about tips and topics relevant to you and the kids in your life. return to the 3t menu return to the 3t menu return to the 3t menu tips for any age tips for any age tips for any age tips for young children tips for young children tips for young children tips for pre-teens and teens tips for pre-teens and teens tips for pre-teens and teens

sharing experiences with a young person on a game or platform can help you build trust and identify risks. spend time online together. regularly remind the young person that you are speaking with them because you care about them and their safety. emphasize care and safety. remain calm, even if you discover concerning behavior. to avoid inducing unnecessary fear, only share age-appropriate information about online risks. avoid alarm. take time to talk when there are no distractions and you can focus 100% on the conversation. be available. being nonjudgmental shows curiosity and caring. it also prevents kids from becoming defensive and shutting down. practice this by giving kids the space to share their thoughts and feelings, without interruption. ask open-ended questions to understand their perspective. be nonjudgmental. ask open-ended questions to invite discussion and to avoid short answers like “yes” or “no.” for example, “what do you like about this game?” or, “how is meeting someone online different from meeting friends at school?” ask open-ended questions. general tips click to explore each. ask open-ended questions. ask open-ended questions. ask open-ended questions. be nonjudgmental. be nonjudgmental. be nonjudgmental. be available. be available. be available. avoid alarm. avoid alarm. avoid alarm. emphasize care and safety. emphasize care and safety. emphasize care and safety. spend time online together. spend time online together. spend time online together. continue continue continue

online safety topics ask how their friends use devices and play online games. discuss the importance of not talking to people they don’t know; stranger danger is online and in person. talk about safe and respectful online interactions. they should only talk to others about what's happening in the game. they should treat others with respect and be treated the same way. discuss staying within platforms approved by a parent or caretaker. tips for ages 3-11 they interpret the world on a literal level, so encourage them to ask questions. focus on safety and avoid details of harm or danger. play games and use devices with them to model safety. discuss safety and health topics that relate to online and offline experiences, like coping with healthy emotions, peer pressure, what “being uncomfortable” feels like, and how to ask for help. it’s important to teach kids about the risks of apps, online relationships, and content sharing. tips for ages 3-11 tips for ages 3-11 tips for ages 3-11 online safety topics online safety topics online safety topics conversations with young children click the tabs to explore each category. then listen to a sample conversation. listen to a conversation. listen to a conversation.

mike’s seven-year-old, frannie, wants to try a new online game that her friends at school are playing. mike downloads the game and reviews it briefly on his own. he notices it’s an open platform where any gamer can talk and interact with any other gamer. he and his daughter sit down, with the app open, to talk about the game. hear a conversation in action. continue continue continue
mike asks frannie to show him around the game. she shows him how to choose a character and collect points. after a few minutes, he talks to her about safety… continue continue continue

mike tells frannie she can have two hours for playing the game each week and tells her he’ll be checking the gaming platform frequently. he also tells frannie he doesn’t feel comfortable with her playing at niki’s until he talks to niki’s parents about it. they wrap up by playing the game together… continue continue continue

let's explore this more. continue continue continue continue mike used simple preventative and age-appropriate conversation techniques with frannie. he kept the conversation light and playful by asking her to share her excitement and knowledge about the game; that way, he could model safe behavior and understand how she wants to use it with her friends. he reinforced online safety by comparing it to discussions they’ve had about in-person safety. he also discussed clear rules about her use of the game and that it’s important for her to tell him if she feels uncomfortable and, if she does, they can figure it out together. good choices. mike used simple preventative and age-appropriate conversation techniques with frannie. he kept the conversation light and playful by asking her to share her excitement and knowledge about the game; that way, he could model safe behavior and understand how she wants to use it with her friends. he reinforced online safety by comparing it to discussions they’ve had about in-person safety. he also discussed clear rules about her use of the game and that it’s important for her to tell him if she feels uncomfortable and, if she does, they can figure it out together. continue continue continue continue continue continue continue he established and discussed clear rules about how she can interact online. he spoke to her in an age-appropriate way about stranger danger online. he asked open-ended questions. he played the game with her. what did mike do well in his conversation with frannie? choose all that apply and click continue.

online safety topics talk about safety and respect with online interactions. discuss short- and long-term consequences of sharing online content, like nude pictures/videos. discuss online exploitation, sextortion, and the process of grooming. share real examples of people using fake identities to exploit and blackmail. share the dangers related to giving away personal information (e.g., home address, phone number, school name, social security number) or meeting an online "friend" in person. discuss the importance of never keeping secrets about online activity, even if they feel uncomfortable or embarrassed. emphasize that predators rely on secrets to exploit. tips for ages 12-18 some pre-teens/teens are exploring their sexuality, and many prioritize social belonging above safety. keep conversations direct and honest about online risks and possible consequences. use real-life stories to talk about what can and does happen. emphasize safety as the priority; let them know mistakes have consequences, but you will always be there to support them. end conversations with encouragement. discuss healthy coping skills; make sure they have at least one healthy adult they’re comfortable talking to. it’s important to teach teens about the risks of apps, online relationships, and content sharing. tips for ages 12-18 tips for ages 12-18 tips for ages 12-18 online safety topics online safety topics online safety topics conversations with pre-teens/teens click the tabs to explore each category. then listen to a sample conversation. listen to a conversation. listen to a conversation.

gloria’s 14-year-old son, lucas, is involved in after-school activities, enjoys school, and is generally happy. but he’s been spending more and more time messaging online and texting friends. she’s heard rumors that kids at his school have been caught sending nude photos to each other. when it’s just the two of them, she decides to talk to lucas about online safety. hear a conversation in action. continue continue continue

gloria and lucas talk about specific examples of respect and risk online, like sextortion and online grooming. she shares a story she’s recently heard about teenagers being sextorted by an adult predator. continue continue continue

gloria talks about other safety guidelines, like not meeting anyone from online in person without permission. she tells lucas that, above all else, he should never be embarrassed to tell her if anything happens—even if he’s made a poor choice—because she’ll support him. she ends the conversation by reminding him that she loves him, and wants him to learn, grow, and have fun online, but wants him to be safe while doing it. continue continue continue

let's explore this more. continue continue continue continue gloria used real-world examples to start the conversation with lucas. because lucas is a teenager, it is age-appropriate for gloria to talk with him directly and specifically about topics like: sexually explicit image exchange, the signs to watch out for with predators online, and how lucas would react in a situation that feels uncomfortable. she also reinforced that if he makes a mistake, she'll support him, regardless of the issue—she loves him and wants him to be safe. ending the conversation this way emphasizes her concern for his safety above all else. good choices. gloria used real-world examples to start the conversation with lucas. because lucas is a teenager, it is age-appropriate for gloria to talk with him directly and specifically about topics like: sexually explicit image exchange, the signs to watch out for with predators online, and how lucas would react in a situation that feels uncomfortable. she also reinforced that if he makes a mistake, she'll support him, regardless of the issue—she loves him and wants him to be safe. ending the conversation this way emphasizes her concern for his safety above all else. continue continue continue continue continue continue continue she said he should never be too ashamed to share if something bad happens; she’ll help him figure it out. she was direct and specific when talking about topics of online respect and safety. she asked open-ended questions. she referred to real-world examples of sexual image exchange. what did gloria do well in her conversation with lucas? choose all that apply and click continue.

*london school of economics, 2021 let’s explore this. in general, research shows that when parents or caretakers talk to their kids and set up age-appropriate safeguards, kids can become resilient users of the internet.* these kids are able to act in an empowered way when encountering potentially harmful or inappropriate content online. but to build their resilience muscle, they need proper technology safeguards and support as they learn how to self-regulate their device and app use. let’s check out some tools for putting these technology safeguards in place. continue continue continue good choice. in general, research shows that when parents or caretakers talk to their kids and set up age-appropriate safeguards, kids can become resilient users of the internet.* these kids are able to act in an empowered way when encountering potentially harmful or inappropriate content online. but to build their resilience muscle, they need proper technology safeguards and support as they learn how to self-regulate their device and app use. let’s check out some tools for putting these technology safeguards in place. continue continue continue *london school of economics, 2021 what do you think? can kids be empowered to respond appropriately to unsafe or disrespectful online content? choose one. yes yes yes yes no no no no

put the right safeguards in place for the child in your life. technology awareness and control click each category to explore more about the topics relevant to you. return to the 3t menu return to the 3t menu return to the 3t menu common apps common apps common apps parental control settings parental control settings parental control settings technology agreement technology agreement technology agreement

are you familiar with common types of platforms? do you recognize any of these apps? choose a response. i recognize all of them. i recognize all of them. i recognize all of them. i recognize some of them. i recognize some of them. i recognize some of them. i don’t recognize any of them. i don’t recognize any of them. i don’t recognize any of them.

gaming apps online gaming apps allow users to game online together. they have open-channel and direct-messaging chat functions, where predators can disguise themselves and then groom young victims using the platform. discord roblox examples return to app menu return to app menu return to app menu livestreaming apps livestreaming apps allow users to record themselves live while strangers watch. predators can use these apps to exploit young people fairly easily. many of these apps use a virtual currency system that predators can send to young people in exchange for explicit videos or photos. examples live.me twitch return to app menu return to app menu return to app menu hidden apps hidden apps are often described in the app store as primarily educational or content sharing, but they have functionality that allows content to be shared secretly. teens or predators use them to secretly share messages, explicit photos, pornography, and more. calculator+ bestsecretfolder examples return to app menu return to app menu return to app menu random video chatters random video chatters randomly match users with people around the world for video chats. they originated as a fun way to make new friends but quickly become a breeding ground for racism, radicalism, and sexual exploitation. omegle holla zoosk examples return to app menu return to app menu return to app menu dating apps dating apps allow you to identify and connect with people in your area. they may have a minimum age limit, but it can be easy to get past that barrier. these apps can be especially dangerous because they register the phone’s location to find local users, which could allow predators to find your child’s school or address. bumble grindr tinder badoo hinge hot or not examples monkey plenty of fish hily return to app menu return to app menu return to app menu anonymous messenger apps anonymous messenger apps are popular among teenagers because they allow people to send their honest opinions of someone without revealing their identity. these apps are also well known for being used for cyberbullying and sexual exploitation. examples lipsi whisper ask.fm yolo return to app menu return to app menu return to app menu no problem! anonymous messenger apps random video chatters dating apps hidden apps livestreaming apps gaming apps click each app type to learn more. continue continue continue well done! anonymous messenger apps random video chatters dating apps hidden apps livestreaming apps gaming apps click each app type to learn more. continue continue continue

parental control settings click each topic to explore more. safety settings inside the home safety settings inside the home safety settings inside the home safety settings outside the home safety settings outside the home safety settings outside the home continue continue continue

continue continue continue let’s explore this more. it’s important to have a technology agreement that suits the practical and safety needs of the adults and kids. items to consider including are: screen/device time limits, parameters around platform and app use, parental controls, monitoring of online interactions, and the types of content kids can engage with. you may also want to include agreements that are shared by everyone (e.g., no device use during meals) and consequences for agreement violations. click here to access a technology agreement sample. click here to access a technology agreement sample. good choices. it’s important to have a technology agreement that suits the practical and safety needs of the adults and kids. items to consider including are: screen/device time limits, parameters around platform and app use, parental controls, monitoring of online interactions, and the types of content kids can engage with. you may also want to include agreements that are shared by everyone (e.g., no device use during meals) and consequences for agreement violations. continue continue continue click here to access a technology agreement sample. click here to access a technology agreement sample. continue continue continue continue identify online content that cannot be shared or engaged with. turn on parental control settings (e.g., network, router, apps, and devices). monitor a young person's texts and chats regularly. require the young person to ask for permission before downloading new apps. create time limitations around screen/device use. choose all that apply and click continue. online traffickers and exploiters know how to target vulnerable individuals. what do you think? which items could be included in a technology agreement?

continue continue continue continue this is tricky! all of these actions are necessary, and you should take them whenever possible. it’s important to know that every platform has different reporting and blocking policies, but regardless of the platform in use, there is always some action you can take to report the incident and help the youth in your life. let’s explore these. good choices. all of these actions are necessary, and you should take them whenever possible. it’s important to know that every platform has different reporting and blocking policies, but regardless of the platform in use, there is always some action you can take to report the incident and help the youth in your life. let’s explore these. continue continue continue continue continue continue continue i would review all messages exchanged between the youth and predator. i would block the person the youth has been communicating with. i would call local law enforcement. i would contact the platform the youth was using. which steps would you take if you learned that a youth in your life had shared a sexually explicit photo with someone online? choose all that apply and click continue.

if you suspect anything suspicious, take action. actions to take log in to the young person's platform account. save all the exchanged messages. 1 2 3 block the individual. research reporting policies for the platform. report to the national center for missing and exploited children and local law enforcement. 4 5 6 support the young person. the resource link at the end of this module includes more information on reporting and hotlines. continue continue continue

the 3 ts should be used regularly. technology awareness and control talk to kids regularly take action to intervene continue having open conversations. revisit technology use and agreements. watch for behaviors that indicate intervention is needed. ready to practice what you’ve just learned? you’ve completed this module! you’re ready to start the next module: a true story. continue continue continue

a note of caution: this module includes mature language and may include readings, media, and discussion around topics such as sexual assault, child sexual abuse, human trafficking, online sexual enticement, domestic violence, and physical violence. hope for justice acknowledges that this content may be difficult and encourages participants to care for their safety and well-being. disclaimer: some of the stories in this module are based on real survivors. names are fictional and images use models to protect survivor identities. a true story start the module start the module start the module keeping kids safe in the digital world

online exploitation starts in the blink of an eye. watch an exploitation attempt based on a true story. continue continue continue technology awareness and control take action to intervene talk to kids regularly
ready to rewind and rewrite jd’s story? continue continue continue

this is tricky. taken individually, each of these is a common teenager behavior or emotion. parents and caretakers should be on alert when a young person displays a combination of these traits, especially over an extended period of time. young people who go online for escape, emotional relief, or a majority of their social connection, can be especially vulnerable to online exploitation. continue continue continue good choices. taken individually, each of these is a common teenager behavior or emotion. parents and caretakers should be on alert when a young person displays a combination of these traits, especially over an extended period of time. young people who go online for escape, emotional relief, or a majority of their social connection, can be especially vulnerable to online exploitation. continue continue continue jd’s mom is concerned. continue continue continue continue he’s talking online with a “friend” whose in-person identity has not been confirmed. he doesn’t seem happy at school. he's spending an excessive amount of time on gaming and social media apps. he’s disengaged during in-person conversations. what signs is jd showing that might indicate an increased vulnerability? choose all that apply and click continue.

let’s explore this more. continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. when initiating conversations about online safety with kids of any age, it’s a good idea to start in a way that will keep communication open. parents and caretakers can create a safe space for young people to share honestly about their online world and experiences. asking questions, showing interest, and making a plan to talk more or play games together are great ways to begin these talks. good choice! when initiating conversations about online safety with kids of any age, it’s a good idea to start in a way that will keep communication open. parents and caretakers can create a safe space for young people to share honestly about their online world and experiences. asking questions, showing interest, and making a plan to talk more or play games together are great ways to begin these talks. continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. tell jd she wants to review the games and apps he uses. show interest in his online world; let him know she wants to make time this weekend to learn about the platforms and games he’s using. tell jd she’s concerned about his screen time and she plans to talk to his dad about it. tell jd to close his computer because it’s not safe to talk to people online. given the signs of concern, what's the best way for jd's mom to approach a conversation with him? choose the best answer and click continue. continue continue continue continue

continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. this is tricky. it's helpful to ask questions to gauge a young person's knowledge and awareness of online dangers. this can lead to sharing real-life online exploitation stories so kids understand the risks. parents and caretakers can follow up with topics like: comparing in-person “stranger danger” to online strangers; predator tactics and how kids can stay safe on platforms; and how to use technology in a way that’s respectful to themselves and others. this allows kids to understand their parents' or caretakers' concern and encourages them to accept or even participate in a prevention strategy. staying focused on safety, instead of demonizing devices or platforms, can keep the dialogue open and focus on the real risk, which is how people use technology, not the technology itself. continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. good choices! it's helpful to ask questions to gauge a young person's knowledge and awareness of online dangers. this can lead to sharing real-life online exploitation stories so kids understand the risks. parents and caretakers can follow up with topics like: comparing in-person “stranger danger” to online strangers; predator tactics and how kids can stay safe on platforms; and how to use technology in a way that’s respectful to themselves and others. this allows kids to understand their parents' or caretakers' concern and encourages them to accept or even participate in a prevention strategy. staying focused on safety, instead of demonizing devices or platforms, can keep the dialogue open and focus on the real risk, which is how people use technology, not the technology itself. jd is resistant to sharing his online world with his mom. continue continue continue continue tell him the platform he’s on is too dangerous for teens. ask him if he knows what online exploitation is and how it happens. tell him that she just heard a real story about online exploitation happening to a teen like him. which techniques could jd’s mom use to keep the conversation open? choose all that apply and click continue.

continue continue continue let’s explore this more. all these are excellent questions to understand how jd is using the apps and platforms. nonjudgmental questions like these show interest in a child’s online world, while opening a deeper discussion about safe online behavior. for example, how would the young person respond if someone online asked to message privately or even meet offline? these questions can also initiate conversations about applying parental control settings on devices and apps and home technology rules that help young people find a healthy balance between their online and offline worlds. remember, exploring apps with a young person shouldn't replace a parent or caretaker's own information gathering about platforms and their parental control settings. continue continue continue good choices! all these are excellent questions to understand how jd is using the apps and platforms. nonjudgmental questions like these show interest in a child’s online world, while opening a deeper discussion about safe online behavior. for example, how would the young person respond if someone online asked to message privately or even meet offline? these questions can also initiate conversations about applying parental control settings on devices and apps and home technology rules that help young people find a healthy balance between their online and offline worlds. remember, exploring apps with a young person shouldn't replace a parent or caretaker's own information gathering about platforms and their parental control settings. jd shows his mom the platforms he uses. continue continue continue continue has anyone asked to message with you privately—on this platform or another app? what personal information about you do people see? can anyone message you at any time? who do you actively message with? tell me about them. what other questions could jd’s mom ask as they’re exploring the platforms together? choose all that apply and click continue.

let’s explore this more. it's important to end online safety conversations with young people in a way that keeps the topic open and ongoing. kids need to know it’s safe to share anything that happens online—without fear of judgment or consequences. safety is the most important thing! a young person should expect this discussion to be revisited as safeguards and agreements are put into place, new platforms crop up, and technology changes. it’s not enough to have the conversation once and expect a young person to stay safe online or know they will be able to identify dangerous people. continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. good choices. it's important to end online safety conversations with young people in a way that keeps the topic open and ongoing. kids need to know it’s safe to share anything that happens online—without fear of judgment or consequences. safety is the most important thing! a young person should expect this discussion to be revisited as safeguards and agreements are put into place, new platforms crop up, and technology changes. it’s not enough to have the conversation once and expect a young person to stay safe online or know they will be able to identify dangerous people. continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. continue continue continue continue tell jd she’s glad he understands and she doesn’t think they’ll need to discuss these topics again. tell him they will create a family technology agreement to stay safe online. let jd know she will do more research on platforms and device settings. make sure jd knows it’s always safe to share anything that happens online with his parents. after they’ve spent time looking at the platforms together, how can jd’s mom wrap up their conversation? choose all that apply and click continue.

continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. let’s explore this more. all of these are excellent starting places for a family technology agreement: establishing screen time limits, parental or caretaker approval of platforms, no taking or sharing of inappropriate content, and no sharing personal information online. it also can be useful for kids to know all family members will have some boundaries around technology use. for example, all family members shut off and charge devices in one central area by 9 p.m. every night. after creating agreements, it’s important to talk to kids about each agreement, hear their input, and establish consequences (e.g., lost device privileges, deletion of an app, etc.) if agreements are broken. continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. good choices! all of these are excellent starting places for a family technology agreement: establishing screen time limits, parental or caretaker approval of platforms, no taking or sharing of inappropriate content, and no sharing personal information online. it also can be useful for kids to know all family members will have some boundaries around technology use. for example, all family members shut off and charge devices in one central area by 9 p.m. every night. after creating agreements, it’s important to talk to kids about each agreement, hear their input, and establish consequences (e.g., lost device privileges, deletion of an app, etc.) if agreements are broken. jd’s parents want to put online safeguards in place. continue continue continue continue jd will not take and/or share inappropriate pictures or videos. jd will not share personal information online. parents approve all platforms or apps used, monitor devices, and know all passcodes. jd has a set amount of screen time each day. what could the technology agreement include? choose all that apply and click continue.

this is tricky. all these are good techniques for keeping communication open with jd. staying engaged and attentive to the online platforms, which are always changing, is key in keeping dialogue open and ensuring safety. similarly, as new technology emerges, there will likely be new forms of parental controls. as a parent or caretaker, it's important to continue to research how to put controls in place. in this case, jd’s parents could ensure they have notifications set up from his devices to block him from downloading without their permission. continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. good choices. all these are good techniques for keeping communication open with jd. staying engaged and attentive to the online platforms, which are always changing, is key in keeping dialogue open and ensuring safety. similarly, as new technology emerges, there will likely be new forms of parental controls. as a parent or caretaker, it's important to continue to research how to put controls in place. in this case, jd’s parents could ensure they have notifications set up from his devices to block him from downloading without their permission. continue the story. continue the story. continue the story. jd’s using a new platform. continue continue continue continue she could sit down and play the game with him. she could ask him about the people he’s met on this platform. she could ask him what's different about this game than the other games he plays. how could jd’s mom keep communication open? choose all that apply and click continue.

use the 3 ts of online safety to keep young people safe. teach kids about online risks and understand how they’re already using platforms. did you make a new friend at school? talk to kids regularly technology awareness and control become familiar with the platforms your kids are on and the technology controls you can use. hey, is that app in our technology agreement? don’t hesitate to intervene if you notice concerning behavior or something unsafe. take action to intervene let’s turn off location sharing. online safety is an ongoing process. create peace of mind by having safeguards in place.

act today! together we can raise awareness and take action to keep young people safe online. you've completed the keeping kids safe in the digital world course! you can now close the window to complete.
